comments.commentBody:
Congratulations, Mr. Faulkner, sir. You are a man of honor and I salute you and the service that you have rendered to our nation.

A big thank you to Mr. Bruni for sharing Mr. Faulkner's story in the New York Times.

My thinking is very similar with that of Thomas Friedman (http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/05/opinion/sunday/compromise-not-a-4-lett.... Forsake of argument, from the premise, "Silicon Valley is now the turbo-engine of our economy and D.C. is the dead hand" I question if growing division stems from confusion re basic moral norms in a society. What are the common moral norms in social interaction re bureaucracy vs. technocracy?

"To put all pieces together, the political leadership needs to work hard to mitigate the divergence in extreme political views." If a community is transitioning from a manufacturing economy to a knowledge-based economy, when I look at the data (http://www.erievitalsigns.org/) and your view that "three themes for long term growth and development (given the data in the economy I reside)"--I wonder if part of the responsibility for division is the education sector?

During last few years, the wealth effect started to show some effect on the economy.  Still some trillions of dollars are set aside outside the market and when more wider class of investors start to feel confidence in the capital markets, we could see wealth effect at wider scale.  However, the labor participation rate still is under the peak level but is slowly trending up at slower rate – that has been the single major impact of the economy.  The participation rate will pick up with the growth of housing sector which has given several optimistic trends but still at the early innings.  The three themes for long-term growth will be development of Oil & Gas sector, new medicines through advancements in Biotechnology, Advancements in Tech industry (within ecosystem of Social, Mobile & Cloud) & these industries will transform US but it will require employees with unique set of skills.  We still require fiscal stimulus to improve fabrics of our infrastructure as to absorb next level growth cycle (to get out of the liquidity trap & tapering already started).  To put all pieces together, the political leadership needs to work hard to mitigate the divergence in extreme political views.
I hope this relieves a bit of Mr. Faulkner's pain in the time he has left.  And kudos to Ms. Brooksher-Yen for successfully pressing the government move quickly.
.. or getting the guy ;)

When I was a kid in the 1940s, movies and ads glamourized smoking and it was widespread among adults we admired and respected.  It was also shunned by many we admired and respected; most parents either forbad or discouraged their children from smoking, which often had the opposite effect.  But the major deterrent among us guys was the belief that smoking hurt your wind and stunted your growth.  We didn't want to do anything that would hurt us making the team or becoming a six-footer.  Both were seen as advantages in getting the girl.

Although I am covered by original Medicare with a Medigap supplement, I  automatically get the annual "Medicare and You" book that summarizes all the Advantage and Part D plans in my area. I am amazed by the size of the "copays" under some of the Advantage plans. I know what my 20% is for a lot of visits to both a PCP and specialists under original Medicare, and am shocked to see that people are routinely paying copays that are twice what I would pay as my 20% share for some visits. I don't think people realize how low original Medicare allowable charges are.

@Le N. ~ In response to your comment " I'd so much rather read a human interest story about somebody who almost died."
This is a story about someone who almost died, a fabulous story about the human will to survive weaved by an extraordinary storyteller, Paul Tough.
Barry Bonds and his steroid enlarged skull in the Hall of Fame = NEVER.
That has been Andy's coaching M.O. during his years as well. K.C. will have to learn to live with it. Andy will not change.

When are NFL coaches going to learn? Prevent defenses only prevent you from winning. Andy Reed and his old school coaches don't deserve to win. How can you blow  that lead? Pathetic coaching, that's how.

We "on the left' are not asking for 'marginal inconveniences' on the 1%.  We are asking for a return to Capital Gains Tax Rates that existed under Clinton.  Going from 15% to 30% means government surpluses, monetary velocity, and jobs.  With so much wealth concentration, doubling Capital Gains Rates really the only avenue left to invigorate the economy.  The rich will have only themselves to blame; they lied to get the favorable rates, saying they were going to "invest.'  Instead, they have just been sitting on the cash, creating a bull market  in a "jobless recovery."  Pigs get fat, hogs go to market.

"Markets don't self-correct..."
Huh - so I guess 300 years of macroeconomics must be thrown out of the door.
I am guessing you mean - the markets don't correct the way that we liberals want them to - so it is a virtual necessity that we monkey with them - regardless of the many examples that monkeying with the free flow of markets creates disasters.
As a matter of course - the two greatest destroyers of human life in history occurred when someone thought they knew better than the 'markets'.

I am willing to pay more for organic food, especially local, because in more cases than not it is better for the environment, less poisonous to streams, the land, oceans, etc. Though hard and dirty work, organic methods are probably less harmful to farm workers. As an organic gardener, I would much rather deal with floating row cover to keep caterpillars off my cabbages than chemicals.

Something tells me that the study you cite by the Heritage Foundation showing 'little-to-no correlation between inequality and mobility across different regions of the country', is going to be shown to be greatly flawed( and by mobility I assume you mean social mobility).

The Times did the nation a great service by publishing the editorial.

Maybe it can continue this discussion by inviting academics to a roundtable for a discussion of the ethical, constitutional and historical issues around the NSA and its current mandate.

“When someone reveals that government officials have routinely and deliberately broken the law, that person should not face life in prison at the hands of the same government.”

Only when there is a much deeper understanding and concern on the part of the people, will there be a call for meaningful change. As of right now, there is no meaningful debate going on among our legislators, much less any kind of division on whether or not something needs to be done. Those who are in favor of the police state are clearly in the majority.

I hope the Times continues to lead on this issue and keep it in the front of our collective consciousness.

Will minimum wage really change things a lot? Many public servants and union members have their pay tied in some part to being above a minimum wage, so more cash to the low paid and more to the public and unionized sector and everyone who buys something shares the cost via higher prices. I have no objection except that no one should be surprised that there is no free lunch here.

Look at the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, now law. Everyone sees higher premiums and higher deductibles. Sure those making more than $250,000 pay even more but Everyone is helping some but for this help would have a hard time. A straight forward tax on everyone would have bought insurance for the 7.5% who needed but could not buy ((another 7.5% could use but didn't buy)).

Looking straight ahead at the problems invites easier and less costly fixes but interest of many who dispense this handout are many and expensive.

NYC has an opportunity to be a creative laboratory for the U.S. With Mayor deBlasio's goal to reduce the inequality inherent in free market capitalism, he may define a pathway for the U.S. to correct capitalism's failure to provide health & education, fair income distribution, & access to decent & affordable housing, efficient transportation, and effective city security and sanitation services. I can envision a golden age that will foster a renaissance in urban living. It can be done & the mayor is off to a good start with his initiative in education.

The Heritage Foundation is gaited by ideological mythology forgetting the primary social necessity for eusocial humans is to pursue a better quality of life through collective effort & helping fellow members of our species.

NYC has political clout in our system of representative government. It has wonderful natural and human resources. The human resources can unleash enormous energy and creativity that can make a huge difference in the future of the U.S.

I am in transportation and was captured decades ago by the creativity of the late Senator Pat Moynihan, who singled out the highly energy efficient, 300 mph, Superconducting Magnetic Levitated transport for passengers and freight trucks invented by Drs. James Powell & Gordon Danby, Powell & Danby's story and Moynihan's vision is told & described in "The Fight for Maglev", Making America the World Leader in 21st Century Transport" and recently, "Maglev America".

I'm with Deadline on this puzzle. It seemed quite easy and the Clue references were obvious. I did find the SE a bit harder, but it still fell almost as fast as I could put in the letters.

Cute theme, but not much challenge.

I love the anti-educationists who insist that offering more and better education  to the have-nots doesn't really matter, that "throwing" money at the problem doesn't help. Meanwhile, these pundits certainly choose the best daycare (nannies), pre-schools, day & boarding schools, colleges, and professional schools money can buy.

If you want to see a correlation between extreme income inequality and the decline of living standards for the working and middle classes, just look at the U.S. since 1981.

The problem with de Blasio is that his proposals fall far short of the New Deal. Expanded pre-K and job training are hopelessly inadequate ways to reduce inequality in an economy where there aren't enough jobs and the ones that do exist don't pay enough.

My cousins, who live in Scandinavia get a lot of bang for the high taxes they pay.  Their parents were all blue collar workers, but because of  free education, including at the university level, they were all able to get white collar jobs and their children have done even better.  They have never had to worry about being bankrupt because of health care costs.  Yes things are expensive there, especially for Americans who come with dollars that are not worth very much anymore.  But if you were to add up the financial burden that Americans pay to have their kids educated, and to pay for health insurances, I would guess that the costs to each of us is as high as those tax rates in Europe.  Socialism in this country is seen as something to be avoided, but if you have seen how other people live in these "socialist" countries, you might be singing a different tune.  Americans need to travel more.

Fellow posters,

You can criticize Mr. Douthat all you want, but his central thesis, you cannot have a de Blasio style socialism without raising taxes on everyone, is spot on. It comes down to a simple example: You could tax everyone in de Blasio's crosshairs at double the current rate, and it would have little effect on income inequality.

To support the welfare state in Europe, the middle class is taxed at a much higher rate on income, and there is a value added tax that runs at nearly 20% on consumer purchases.

We have been in an economic slump since 2007 or 8. Even before that we were suffering high unemployment and growth below trend. The last really good year was 2000, 14 years ago.

People keep expecting us to pull out and we keep being disappointed. True recovery to trend would mean growing at about 2.7 percent a year, 2 percent for progress, .7 for population growth, plus a lot more to make up the more than 10 percent we have lost.
This does not seem to be happening.

Part of the problem is we are suffering from early effects of the technological singularity. We are advancing faster and faster which means investments become obsolete very quickly. This creates a shortage of good safe places to put your money.

The over supply of savings drives interest rates to the zero bound. With inflation interest on safe investments is less than zero.

More dangerous investments, like corporate stock have done much better, but they maybe much more dangerous than many realize. The rapid progress may many of these investments obsolete.

Note I am writing about slow growth and a slump and rapid progress happening at the same time.

This is largely because our economic measures were created in an industrial age and by those measures we advance slowly. But the information age is changing our world at a very rapid rate.

By the way I don't really believe in the techological singularity, and it is not necessary for the argument, it is just a hook.

And those 900 will at retirement receive the same Social Security check as a person making 117k. It is a retirement plan, not a soak the rich, progressive tax plan.   If you remove the cap you either have to pay people at the top a gigantic monthly check or decide that the system now has no connection between payments and benefits.  If you want to have that fight then go for it and let's see if Social Security survives it.

Great comments, Gemli, Rima Regis, Jack Chicago and Karen Garcia. When the columnist writes about the rich " being squeezed" to "benefit a well compensated public sector and preserve bureaucracies that ought to be reformed", I am baffled.  If certain "bureaucracies" need to "be reformed" , what are those bureaucracies and why and how should they be reformed? Who are these "well compensated public sector" workers for whom the rich are " being squeezed"?   References to predigested ideas from right wing think tanks don't help me understand the basis for this columnist's  concerns.

Think Progress published a piece on the Social Security piece. Based on what they've earned so far, the 900 most wealthy people in the US are done paying into the fund, as of the fourth day of the first month of the year!

"While almost all working Americans will pay into Social Security through their paychecks throughout the year, the 900 wealthiest people in the country won’t. That’s because the highest-earning 0.0001 percent of the U.S. — many of them corporate CEOs — made $117,000 in the first two days of the year, which is the maximum annual income that is subject to Social Security taxes under federal law."

http://thinkprogress.org/economy/2014/01/03/3118281/rich-social-security...

We need more people like Bernie Sanders and not the likes of Alan Simpsons and those to his right.

John in Hartford:

" I believe it's estimated they cost about 13% more to operate than normal Medicare and generally offer higher reimbursement so of course providers like them. "

Can you prove this statement about Medicare Advantage plans? Where I live I have the impression that providers don't like Medicare Advantage at all. I don't know a single doctor at either of the two academic medical centers with which I have experience that accepts Medicare Advantage patients. The first thing their staff say to a new patient who walks in the door and says his/her coverage is Medicare is "no Medicare HMOs, only regular Medicare!"

Yes Ross--any attempts to even marginally address some of the pressing issues of social inequality, and we're immediately on the path to Scandinavian socialism.

Circle the wagons!!!
